title: 108_hr3683
content: The Act titled "Cameron Gulbransen Kids and Cars Safety Act of 2003" aims to evaluate devices and technology to reduce child injury and death from parked or unattended motor vehicles. The Secretary of Transportation will evaluate devices to reduce child injury and death outside parked vehicles and technology to prevent harm to children left unattended in parked vehicles. A report on the findings must be submitted to Congress within one year of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of Transportation must complete any rulemaking regarding power windows and switches within 6 months of submitting a report to Congress on child safety devices and technology to prevent harm to children in parked vehicles. SEC. 3. DATABASE FOR TRACKING INJURIES AND DEATHS IN NONTRAFFIC EVENTS. The Secretary of Transportation will establish a database to collect data on injuries and deaths in nontraffic, noncrash events involving motor vehicles. Information to be included in the database consists of vehicle details, operator presence, age of individuals involved, technology for detecting objects, and the extent of injuries. The Secretary of Transportation will establish a database to collect data on injuries and deaths in nontraffic, noncrash events involving motor vehicles. The database will include details on the degree of injury, location of the event, and other information as prescribed. The information will be made available to the public through an Internet page and annual reports. The Secretary of Transportation will evaluate technologies for preventing collisions behind motor vehicles and submit a report to Congress within one year. Additionally, motor vehicle safety standards requiring backup detection devices will be established. The Secretary of Transportation will prescribe motor vehicle safety standards requiring backup detection devices to be installed on new vehicles. These standards will be phased in over a 3-year period, with light trucks needing to comply within 2 years. The Secretary of Transportation will require backup detection devices on new vehicles, phased in over a 3-year period. Light trucks must comply within 2 years, while other passenger motor vehicles specified by the Secretary must comply within 3 years. The Secretary of Transportation will prescribe motor vehicle safety standards for power windows and sunroofs within 1 year of this Act, ensuring they do not cause harm and including child-safe switches and auto reverse technology.
